text.0: to thee will send praise and bring oblation as thou hast merited lauds when we invoked thee.
text.1: a fountain in the desert art thou agni o ancient king to man who fain would worship.
text.2: thou unto whom resort the gathered people as the kine seek the warm stall o most youthful.
text.3: thou art the messenger of gods and mortals and goest glorious with thy light between them.
text.4: making thee grow as twere some noble infant thy mother nurtures thee with sweet affection.
text.5: over the desert slopes thou passest longing and seekest like some beast set free thy fodder.
text.6: foolish are we o wise and free from error verily agni thou dost know thy grandeur.
text.7: there lies the form he moves and licks and swallows and as houselord kisses the youthful maiden.
text.8: he rises ever fresh in ancient fuel smokebannered gray he makes the wood his dwelling.
text.9: no swimmer steer he presses through the waters and to his place accordant mortals bear him.
text.10: like thieves who risk their lives and haunt the forest the twain with their ten girdles have secured him.
text.11: this is a new hymn meant for thee o agni yoke as it were thy car with parts that glitter.
text.12: homage and prayer are thine o jātavedas and this my song shall evermore exalt thee.
text.13: agni protect our children and descendants and guard with everwatcliful care our bodies.
